current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
Recognizing the need to improve physical
		  access to many federally funded facilities for all people of the United States,
		  particularly people with disabilities.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following concurrent resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text:
recognizes the immense hardships that
			 people with disabilities in the United States must overcome every day;

reaffirms its
			 support of the Act entitled

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
An Act to insure that certain buildings
			 financed with Federal funds are so designed and constructed as to be accessible
			 to the physically handicapped

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and encourages full compliance with such Acts;

and Federal agencies install power-assisted
			 doors at post offices and other federally funded facilities, respectively, to
			 ensure equal access for all people of the United States; and

text.#text:
pledges to
			 continue to work to identify and remove the barriers that prevent all people of
			 the United States from having equal access to the services provided by the
			 Federal Government.
Whereas, in 2012, 12 percent of the civilian population in the United States reported having a disability;

Whereas, in 2012, 16 percent of veterans, amounting to
			 more than 3,500,000 people, received service-related disability benefits;

Whereas, in 2011, the percentage of working-age people in the United States who reported
			 having a work limitation due to a disability was 7 percent, which  is a 20-year high;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (referred to in this preamble as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
An Act to insure that
			 certain buildings financed with Federal funds are so designed and constructed
			 as to be accessible to the physically handicapped

text.#text: Whereas automatic doors, though not mandated by either the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (referred to in this preamble as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Architectural and
			 Transportation Barriers Compliance Board

text.#text: Whereas a report commissioned by the

Whereas States and municipalities have begun to recognize
			 the importance of automatic doors in improving accessibility;

Whereas the laws of the State of Connecticut require
			 automatic doors in certain shopping malls and retail businesses, the laws of
			 the State of Delaware require automatic doors or calling devices for newly
			 constructed places of accommodation, and the laws of the District of Columbia
			 have a similar requirement;

Whereas the Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings
			 Service, published by the General Services Administration, requires automation of
			 at least one exterior door for all newly constructed or renovated facilities
			 managed by the General Services Administration, including post offices;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: concerned a post office or other facility of the

text.#text:
Whereas from 2006 to 2011, 71 percent of the complaints
			 received by the

Whereas approximately 3,200,000 people visit 1 of
			 the 31,857 post offices in the United States each day; and

Whereas the United States was founded on principles of
			 equality and freedom, and these principles require that all people, including 
			 people with disabilities, are able to engage as equal members of society: Now,
			 therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 SCON 26 IS: Recognizing the need to improve physical access to many federally funded facilities for all people of the United States, particularly people with disabilities.
